body.p: Your letter and Walts came all right and glad enough was I hear that you are getting a little better. You must have had a hard time Mother being sick so long but do not get discouraged and I hope you will soon be as well as ever.

We have Just moved our camp. The place werewhere we were first was a hill without a tree or any sort of shade. werewhere we are now there are plenty of shade trees so that we are very comfortable. I am Just as well and hearty as can be I have slept out in the rain and on the ground but have not felt a bit the worse for it so I think I can go through like a book. When we first came here our camp was fired into for three or four nights in succession there were four or five shots fired each night and we could hear the balls whiz through the camp but
no one was struck. I and half a dozen others were sent out to scout about and see what we could find we took our pistols and India rubber blankets and lay down in the grass about 200 yards from each other (the place werewhere we are is about like Bedford) we were out two nights and brought in about a dozen chaps but they were all let go as there was nothing against them but hanging around the camp. I and two others were sent out the other day to arestarrest a secession soldier from Harpers Ferry who it is suposedsupposed came on here as a spy. We went out in the city the chap that gave us the information shewed us the house and we went in and took him and brought him to camp he was sent to Fort McHenry the same day to be tried for a spy. This city is a regular secession place as we walk through the streets in the city the Women and children
make a regular practice of saying as we pass them hurahhurrah for Jeff Davis the men dontdon't say anything but you can see by the looks of the most of them that they dontdon't like us at all. This city was placed under Marshal law yesterday and the celebrated Marshal Kane was arestedarrested and sent to the Fort. It kicked up quite an excitement in the city but they did not go any further than to stand on the corners and growl. It would not have been well for them to have made any row as there are about 8000 Troops encamped about here with a Splendid Battery of ArtileryArtillery of 8 peicespieces the BateryBattery and two of the regiments are from MassachusetsMassachusetts and they would like very mutchmuch to get square for the afairaffair on the 19th of April.

Well Mother the three Months is going fast and I shall soon be with you
again. I see some very foolish articles in the papers about us sutchsuch as not haveinghaving any thing to eat for 36 hours and being almost naked but you must not believe any thing of the kind as we are as well off as we could expect You speak in your letter of sending me on some Money. We expect to get our pay from Government in the course of a few days but if we do not I have enough to last me untilluntil I get home. Mother you need not woryworry about me at all as I am not in want of anything and I dontdon't believe we shalshall see any fighting at all. I was sent out on a scout again last night I went all around outside of the picket guard and down in the city but after ten O Clock it was as quiet as Brooklyn Well good bye Mother give my love to all and let me hear from you again right away.
